awd_titl_txt: Securing Legacy Seismic Data to Enable Future Discoveries: Albuquerque, NM - September 2019
awd_abstract_narration:
This workshop will bring together stakeholders from federal agencies, national labs, and universities who are data, domain, and computational scientists to advance community goals for creating the framework for digital preservation and access to developing digital collections. Discussion will also include the tools necessary to make these data ready for research usage. Invited keynote speakers will frame the discussions and all participants will have a chance to contribute through breakout groups, interactive polling, and poster sessions.The writing group will summarize the discussions in a document addressing the two broad goals of the workshop: Goal 1: Work towards developing the framework for preservation of longitudinal seismic data. This includes recommendations for prioritizing scanning efforts, defining metadata and data imaging standards to improve discovery and (re)use, and identifying the associated technical and social challenges. Goal 2: Create an interdisciplinary network of data, domain, and computational scientists to facilitate management, access, and use of digitally imaged legacy data.

New seismological data mining methods are supporting discoveries and cross-disciplinary research across Earth system science. Such research is challenged by the relatively short time period of observation for which digital records are readily available. Historical data, recorded on paper and other physical media, potentially extend the time period of Earth observation to many decades. However, if such dark data are to be preserved and made available digitally to harness the data revolution, there are compelling challenges. The historical data are largely siloed; data are only available to scientists who can commit to traveling to specific archives or from archives capable of serving data requests. In addition, some of the physical media have been damaged or lost and/or at risk of losing stewardship. Hence, it is imperative that the community organize to preserve as well as make available these irreplaceable collections. The workshop will provide support for early-career and participants from under-represented groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

por.por_cntn:
New seismological data mining methods are supporting discoveries and cross-disciplinary research across Earth system science. Such research is challenged by the relatively short time period of observation for which digital records are readily available. Historical data, recorded on paper and other physical media, potentially extend the time period of Earth observation to many decades. However, if such dark data are to be preserved and made available digitally to harness the data revolution, there are compelling challenges. The historical data are largely siloed; data are only available to scientists who can commit to traveling to specific archives or from archives capable of serving data requests. In addition, some of the physical media have been damaged or lost and/or at risk of losing stewardship. Hence, it is imperative that the community organize to preserve as well as make available these irreplaceable collections. Other countries are proactively addressing these challenges by imaging select records from their collections in recognition of their scientific value and cultural legacy.

With the relative recent arrival of continuous digital data, the scientific community continues to discover new phenomena and relationships among diverse Earth systems. A better picture of phenomena such as the earthquake cycle, magmatic systems, and the solid earth's response to climate change can be drawn by incorporating more observations from the historic record. The emerging use of machine learning in the geosciences shows future promise in finding signal and patterns, extracting previously unrecognized features in big data. Analog seismograms are an untapped resource. 

To be accessible for such studies and available to modern techniques the analog data must be accessible in digital form. If converted to digital media, these collections conservatively represent upwards of 100's of petabytes of raw image data. Conversion to digital times series may not be necessary for all studies but continued improvements to algorithms are needed to reduce the need for human intervention.

Goal 1: Work towards developing the framework for preservation of longitudinal seismic data. This includes recommendations for prioritizing scanning efforts, defining metadata and data imaging standards to improve discovery and (re)use, and identifying the associated technical and social challenges. 

Goal 2: Create an interdisciplinary network of data, domain, and computational scientists to facilitate management, access, and use of digitally imaged legacy data.

In addressing these goals, we convened a 3-day workshop bringing together stakeholders from federal agencies, national labs, and universities who are data, domain, and computational scientists to advance community goals for creating the framework for digital preservation and access to developing digital collections. Discussions included the tools necessary to make these data ready for research usage.

Workshop participants identified 8 community needs to advance these goals: 1. Creating a catalog of analog seismic data holdings, 2. Highlighting research applications of legacy data through a publications database, 3. Creating FAIR compliant metadata standards, 4. Identifying pilot projects for discovery and reuse, 5. Identifying strategies to enable future research, 6. Identifying new technologies to reduce human intervention in the work flow,  7. Attracting a broader scientific community, and 8. Creating a larger user community through outreach at all career levels.

In addressing these needs, the project has proposed international metadata standards for the exchange and reuse of legacy seismogram records, created a website to aid discovery of repositories of scanned images, and continues its outreach promoting sessions on reuse and preservation of legacy data in creating a community of international users.

Intellectual Merit

This project brought together leading US and international scientists together for cross- and inter-disciplinary discussion on preservation, processing, and exchange of legacy analog seismograms. The community continues discussion addressing the human resource, social, and technical challenges facing analog seismogram recovery, preservation, accessibility and use, including both seismological/Earth sciences and AI/ML perspectives. The community continues to share experiences and best practices, develop collaborations, and propose new and innovative approaches to and increase the impact of legacy data on communities in science and society.

Broader Impact

The project engaged the international community by promoting workshop outcomes and gathering feedback through sponsored sessions at relevant scientific meetings. This has led to a formal proposal for international data exchange standards and international collaboration. Interdisciplinary research combining computational, big data, and domain expertise with observations derived from potentially decades or even a century of legacy seismic data offers promise for new insights into Earth processes from natural and anthropogenic activities including, but not limited to, earthquake and volcanic hazards and atmospheric events.

 


Last Modified: 02/18/2022
Modified by: Lorraine Hwang
